title: Between 26 January 2021 and 31 December 2021, how many members of the Politburo will Chinese state media announce have been arrested and/or expelled from their posts?
preds: Barring a New Year's Eve surprise . . .
Still possible before the end of the year, but no indications.
Commenter prompted that the forecast is only for the end of 2021.

It is likely that 1 member of the Politburo might be removed, given how Bo Xilai and Sun Zhengcai - both politburo members in 2012 and 2017 respectively, and removed in the run up to the Party Congress. As the power struggles intensify, I would expect there to be at least 1 casualty.
Recent news regarding the Finance Minister might increase the possibility of at least one this year, but holding strong with zero.
It doesn’t seem to be happening at the current moment so it looks like we need to fall back onto the base rate. There are only a few months remaining
A little surprise that no one has been expelled yet this year.

This forecast is based on:
1-Xi Jinping is going to strenght his control till 2035's & Speech about the necessity to deter any rivals to The regime& China means more actions towards rival( Supporters of Hu in the Politburo at several ranks) 》》 further reading
https://asia.nikkei.com/static/vdata/china2017/newsgraphics/chinese-communist-party-leaders/index.html
** The infogarphs tell there is still efforts from Xi to get ride of some Hu Faction& on the bias or un clear situation. 2-It is not likely to see a coup in china wich stop this probability brcause Xi Jinping is already The chairman of central military commission and his faction in Politburo are in impressive military positions to stop/deny or at least to back a coup against the Big brother Xi:
https://www.lowyinstitute.org/publications/after-xi#sec44506 3-Xi Jinping approved using the wide use of data which is will make problems with Hu Faction.

Xi's recent speech: "We must tighten the Party’s organizational system, work hard to train high-caliber officials who have both moral integrity and professional competence, remain committed to improving Party conduct, upholding integrity, and combating corruption, and root out any elements that would harm the Party’s advanced nature and purity and any viruses that would erode its health. " http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/
It seems increasingly likely that if any memo is removed it will be done quietly.

Assuming 10 % chance that a member is removed in one year. So: 0.1 * (7 / 12) = 6 % for one
0.06^2 = 0 % for two or more
Since Jin eliminated the Bo cadre is very much now a Jin controlled buro.

Entering a period of leadership stability.  Corruption purges have gone far enough for ccp leadership.  Diminishing returns now, especially given increasing superpower conflict. It's more of a circle the wagons moment
Xi will continue his power consolidation
Taking a second look, now seems quite unlikely, period.

Xi Jinping has solidified his power base in China following the performance during the COVID 19 Pandemic. After the initial failures of the early pandemic period (and the silencing of dissenters such as citizen journalists and doctors) the quick action and harsh lockdowns impressed the Chinese people of its effectiveness. This effectiveness against the spread of the pandemic further impressed most Chinese citizens as they saw their counterparts in the West get ravaged by the disease. Xi Jinping will crush anyone who is out of line, and there is a ongoing lite-purge of the CCP Police. The heirs of Jiang Zemin and Deng Xiaoping are silent for now biding their time and hiding their true intention. We must remember that back in 2012 that Xi Jinping sidelined Bo Xilai and imprisoned the intelligence chief, the remaining members of the politburo will not forget. So maybe one if Xi wants to make another example but equally likely it is zero this year. However, it must be said that there are unconfirmed rumors of several assassination attempts on Xi's life (likely in my opinion due to constitutional changes made in 2018, which pissed off a lot of people due to changes in term limits i.e. making Xi de facto President for life). If there are two or more expelled, then it will because a attempt got close to succeeding.
Four members of the politburo were expelled while sitting on the committee since 1990. I used that rate to come up with these estimates.

Looking at the 2 previous poliburo's, a member had a 1,6% change of being expelled in the 18th buro and a 3,2% change of being expelled in the 17th buro. 
The the current political climate looks more like that during the 17th buro than the 18th so I start with 3,2%. As mentioned by other forecasters the coming period will be more turbulent because Xi Jinping will probably go against precedent and stay for at least another 5 years. The announced anti corruption drive in the security forces will also increase tension and shows a larger power struggle. Also took into consideration the current consensus.
Chinese Politik will getting more agressive, so I think they will more politikal change . . .
A purge of the police is starting.  Looks like a round of consolidation of power.  Anything could happen, going with equal forecasts (nearly)
unable to locate recent expulsions which would imply Xi has completed his purge
It's very rare to expel a sitting Politburo member and Xi's picks account for a sizable share of the current line up

"From the last quarter of 2020 onwards, however, several officials and state-owned enterprise (SOE) chiefs with the rank of vice minister or above have been nabbed for taking ill-gotten gains from associates and friends seeking favors. They include the vice-mayor of Chongqing Deng Huilin (邓恢林); vice-governor of Qinghai Wen Guodong (文国栋); chairman of the China State Shipbuilding Industry Corp (CSIC) Hu Wenming (胡问鸣), and chief account of China Oil and Foodstuffs Corp (COFCO) Luo Jiamang (骆家駹). The four were kicked out of the party at the beginning of this year following investigation for economic crimes (China Daily, January 5; Caixin, October 27, 2020). On January 5, the nation was shocked when Lai Xiaomin (赖小民), former chairman of the state-controlled financial giant China Huarong Asset Management Corp., was given a death sentence for pocketing bribes totaling 1.8 billion RMB (a little under $278 million). Since the era of Reform and Opening, Lai’s case represents one of the very few instances of a vice ministerial-level cadre being sentenced to death for corruption (People’s Daily, January 6; RTHK, January 5)."
https://jamestown.org/program/xi-jinping-boosts-the-partys-control-and-his-own-authority/

The Economist noted that a purge of the nationwide "security estblishment" started on 27 Feb.  That considered, without doing any fancy math or models, It seems reasonable to assume that one Politburo member will resign or otherwise be removed from their position. More than one would suggest the possibility that there may be some actual organized opposition to the Boss.

For how many Politburo members are expelled or arrested, I will use the data from this academic paper (Figure 4. Giant tigers.) ->
https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/figure/10.1080/10670564.2018.1497911?scroll=top&needAccess=true# For this forecast, I will assume a Politburo member being disciplined as the table shows equals their arrest or expulsion. Therefore, looking at the 5 previous politburos  ->
0 Member Lost = 20% = 1/5
1 Members Lost = 60% = 3/5
x>=2 Members Lost = 20%   = 1/5 However, with these politburos taking place over 5 years and with 10 months left ->
1 = 10% = 60% * (10 / (12*5))
x>=2 = 3% = 20% * (10 / (12*5)) 0 Members Lost = 87% = 100% - 10% - 3% I am not aware of any changes made during the current 19th Politburo and I find the articles below persuasive in that the 19th is staffed by Xi Xinping loyalists unlike the previous 18th where there were multiple changes. https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/chinas-xi-stacks-25-member-politburo-with-loyalists
https://macropolo.org/analysis/the-ties-that-bind-xi-people-politburo/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party#Changes_during_term

@timothytfchan analysis is convincing to me.
there is not much more to be gained by Xi by overt demonstration of power.
A new way forward. Maybe I’ll watch the news later and see something about it?
Long time since last expulsion lowers base rate but also makes me think that a further demonstration of authority could be forthcoming.
I agree with the excellent analysis of @timothytfchan that it seems unlikely that 2 or more would be necessary at this point, from Xi's perspective.

I'm not sure why the crowd thinks it's more likely that at least 1 person is arrested/expelled than not. As far as I know Xi has already largely consolidated power. Continuing to expel/arrest high ranking people is going to be politically costly and unnecessary. The current Politburo also seems quite loyal to him. Doesn't look like anyone was expelled from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/16th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party or https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party or https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/14th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party People arrested/expelled from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/17th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party
Bo Xilai (2012)
Xu Caihou (2014, after end of term)
Zhou Yongkang (2013, after end of term)
Guo Boxiong (2015, after end of term) People arrested/expelled from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party
Ling Jihua (2014)
Sun Zhengcai (2017) Note that Xi's rise overlapped with the periods during which the 17th and 18th Politburos existed. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party
"The 19th Politburo was elected at the first plenary session of the 19th Central Committee in October 2017." For ~3 years there haven't been any arrests/expulsions.  https://macropolo.org/analysis/the-ties-that-bind-xi-people-politburo/
"Approximately 60% (15 members) of the 19th Politburo have direct ties to Xi, up from around 20% (five members) of the 18th Politburo (see Tables 1 and 2)." Further reading: https://www.orfonline.org/research/the-rise-of-the-xi-gang/

I’ll keep it simple. Understand China pre cultural Revolution. Then you understand why current China culture of reporting good numbers is important. Keynesian economics has limits. So do the oppressed. Mao Zedong Figures may rise. The consequences of Kissinger national security policy. Maybe a war will be avoided?

Dangerous question to ask! Left hand right hand. Why ask it?  Expelled? Does killed or murdered count? Who will be blamed? As a child I remember reading some garbage in a history book about ww1 started cuz some duke was murdered. Why did ww1 start? Crazy “stuff” for sure.
71 years old: 6 (Li Zhanshu, Wang Chen, Xu Qiliang, Sun Chunlan, Yang Jiechi, Zhang Youxia)
